[Lieutenant Colonel](/wiki/Lieutenant_colonel_\(United_Kingdom\) "Lieutenant
colonel \(United Kingdom\)") **Percival Harrison Fawcett**
[DSO](/wiki/Distinguished_Service_Order "Distinguished Service Order") (18
August 1867 – [during or after](/wiki/Declared_death_in_absentia "Declared
death in absentia") 1925) was a British [geographer](/wiki/Geography
"Geography"), [artillery officer](/wiki/Royal_Artillery "Royal Artillery"),
[cartographer](/wiki/Cartography "Cartography"),
[archaeologist](/wiki/Archaeology "Archaeology") and
[explorer](/wiki/Exploration "Exploration") of South America. Along with his
eldest son, Fawcett [disappeared](/wiki/Missing_person "Missing person") in
1925 during an expedition to find "[Z](/wiki/Lost_City_of_Z "Lost City of Z")"
– his name for an ancient [lost city](/wiki/Lost_city "Lost city"), which he
and others believed to exist and to be the remains of [El
Dorado](/wiki/El_Dorado "El Dorado"), in the [jungles of
Brazil](/wiki/Amazon_rainforest "Amazon rainforest").[1]

## Biography[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Percy_Fawcett&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Biography")]

### Early life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Percy_Fawcett&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Early life")]

Percy Fawcett was born on 18 August 1867 in [Torquay](/wiki/Torquay
"Torquay"), [Devon](/wiki/Devon "Devon"), England, to [Edward Boyd
Fawcett](/wiki/Edward_Fawcett "Edward Fawcett") and Myra Elizabeth (née
MacDougall).[2] He received his education at [Newton Abbot](/wiki/Newton_Abbot
"Newton Abbot") Proprietary College along with [Bertram Fletcher
Robinson](/wiki/Bertram_Fletcher_Robinson "Bertram Fletcher Robinson"). Percy
Fawcett's [India](/wiki/India "India")-born father was a Fellow of the [Royal
Geographical Society](/wiki/Royal_Geographical_Society "Royal Geographical
Society") (RGS). His elder brother [Edward Douglas
Fawcett](/w/index.php?title=Edward_Douglas_Fawcett&action=edit&redlink=1
"Edward Douglas Fawcett \(page does not exist\)") (1866–1960) was a mountain
climber, Eastern occultist and author of philosophical books and popular
[adventure novels](/wiki/Adventure_fiction "Adventure fiction").[3]

Fawcett attended the [Royal Military Academy,
Woolwich](/wiki/Royal_Military_Academy,_Woolwich "Royal Military Academy,
Woolwich") as a cadet, being commissioned as a lieutenant of the [Royal
Artillery](/wiki/Royal_Artillery "Royal Artillery") on 24 July 1886.[4] On 13
January 1896 he was appointed [adjutant](/wiki/Adjutant "Adjutant")[5] of the
[1st Cornwall (Duke of Cornwall's) Artillery
Volunteers](/wiki/1st_Cornwall_\(Duke_of_Cornwall%27s\)_Artillery_Volunteers
"1st Cornwall \(Duke of Cornwall's\) Artillery Volunteers"),[6] and was
promoted to captain on 15 June 1897.[7] He later served in
[Trincomalee](/wiki/Trincomalee "Trincomalee"), [Ceylon](/wiki/Sri_Lanka "Sri
Lanka"), where he also met his future wife Nina Agnes Paterson, whom he
married in January 1901 after having previously ended their engagement. They
had two sons, Jack (born 1903) and Brian (1906–1984), and one daughter, Joan
(1910–2005). He joined the RGS himself in 1901 in order to study surveying and
mapmaking. Later, he worked for the [British Secret
Service](/wiki/Secret_Intelligence_Service "Secret Intelligence Service") in
[North Africa](/wiki/North_Africa "North Africa") while pursuing the
surveyor's craft. He served for the war office on [Spike Island, County
Cork](/wiki/Spike_Island,_County_Cork "Spike Island, County Cork") from 1903
to 1906, where he was promoted to major on 11 January 1905.[8] He became
friends with authors [H. Rider Haggard](/wiki/H._Rider_Haggard "H. Rider
Haggard") and [Arthur Conan Doyle](/wiki/Arthur_Conan_Doyle "Arthur Conan
Doyle"); the latter used Fawcett's [Amazonian](/wiki/Amazon_basin "Amazon
basin") field reports as an inspiration for his novel _[The Lost
World](/wiki/The_Lost_World_\(Conan_Doyle_novel\) "The Lost World \(Conan
Doyle novel\)")_.

### Early
expeditions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Percy_Fawcett&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Early expeditions")]

Fawcett's first expedition to South America was in 1906 (being seconded for
service there on 2 May[9]) when at the age of 39 he travelled to Brazil to map
a jungle area at the border of Brazil and Bolivia at the behest of the Royal
Geographical Society. The Society had been commissioned to map the area as a
third party unbiased by local [national interests](/wiki/Nationalism
"Nationalism"). He arrived in [La Paz](/wiki/La_Paz "La Paz"),
[Bolivia](/wiki/Bolivia "Bolivia") in June. Whilst on the expedition in 1907,
Fawcett claimed to have seen and shot a 62 foot long [giant
anaconda](/wiki/Giant_anaconda "Giant anaconda"), a claim for which he was
ridiculed by scientists. He reported other mysterious animals unknown to
zoology, such as a small [cat-like dog](/wiki/Mitla_\(cryptid\) "Mitla
\(cryptid\)") about the size of a [foxhound](/wiki/Foxhound "Foxhound"), which
he claimed to have seen twice, or the giant Apazauca spider which was said to
have poisoned a number of locals.[10][11]

Fawcett made seven expeditions between 1906 and 1924. He was mostly amicable
with the locals through gifts, patience and courteous behaviour. In 1908, he
traced the source of the [Rio Verde](/wiki/Verde_River_\(Guapor%C3%A9_River\)
"Verde River \(Guaporé River\)") (Brazil) and in 1910 made a journey to [Heath
River](/wiki/Heath_River "Heath River") (on the border between
[Peru](/wiki/Peru "Peru") and Bolivia) to find its source, having retired from
the British army on 19 January.[12] After a 1913 expedition, he supposedly
claimed to have seen dogs with double noses. These may have been [Double-nosed
Andean tiger hounds](/wiki/Double-nosed_Andean_tiger_hound "Double-nosed
Andean tiger hound").[13]

Based on documentary research, Fawcett had by 1914 formulated ideas about a
"lost city" he named "Z" somewhere in the [Mato Grosso](/wiki/Mato_Grosso
"Mato Grosso") region of Brazil. He theorized that a complex civilization once
existed in the Amazon region and that isolated ruins may have survived.[14]
Fawcett also found a document known as [Manuscript 512](/wiki/Manuscript_512
"Manuscript 512") ([pt](https://pt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manuscrito_512
"pt:Manuscrito 512")), written after explorations made in the
[sertão](/wiki/Sert%C3%A3o "Sertão") of the state of [Bahia](/wiki/Bahia
"Bahia"), and housed at the National Library of [Rio de
Janeiro](/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro "Rio de Janeiro"). It is believed to be by
Portuguese [bandeirante](/wiki/Bandeirante "Bandeirante") [João da Silva
Guimarães](/w/index.php?title=Jo%C3%A3o_da_Silva_Guimar%C3%A3es&action=edit&redlink=1
"João da Silva Guimarães \(page does not exist\)")
([pt](https://pt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jo%C3%A3o_da_Silva_Guimar%C3%A3es "pt:João
da Silva Guimarães")), who wrote that in 1753 he'd discovered the ruins of an
ancient city that contained arches, a statue, and a temple with hieroglyphics;
the city is described in great detail without providing a specific location.
This city became a secondary destination for Fawcett, after "Z". (See
Fawcett's own book _Exploration Fawcett_.)

At the beginning of the [First World War](/wiki/First_World_War "First World
War") Fawcett returned to Britain to serve with the Army as a Reserve Officer
in the Royal Artillery, volunteering for duty in [Flanders](/wiki/Flanders
"Flanders"), and commanding an [artillery brigade](/wiki/Artillery_brigade
"Artillery brigade") despite the fact that he was nearly fifty years of age.
He was promoted from major to lieutenant-colonel on 1 March 1918,[15] and
received three [mentions in despatches](/wiki/Mentions_in_despatches "Mentions
in despatches") from [Douglas Haig](/wiki/Douglas_Haig,_1st_Earl_Haig "Douglas
Haig, 1st Earl Haig"), in November 1916,[16] November 1917,[17] and November
1918,[18] and was also awarded the [Distinguished Service
Order](/wiki/Distinguished_Service_Order "Distinguished Service Order") in
June 1917.[19]

After the war Fawcett returned to Brazil to study local wildlife and
[archaeology](/wiki/Archaeology "Archaeology"). In 1920, he made a solo
attempt to search for "Z", but ended after suffering from a fever and shooting
his pack animal.[14]

### Final
expedition[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Percy_Fawcett&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Final expedition")]

In 1925, with funding from a London-based group of financiers known as the
Glove,[20] Fawcett returned to Brazil with his eldest son Jack and Jack's best
and longtime friend, Raleigh Rimell, for an exploratory expedition to find
"Z". Fawcett left instructions stating that if the expedition did not return,
no rescue expedition should be sent lest the rescuers suffer his fate.

Fawcett was a man with years of experience travelling, and had brought
equipment such as canned foods, powdered milk, guns, flares, a
[sextant](/wiki/Sextant "Sextant"), and a
[chronometer](/wiki/Marine_chronometer "Marine chronometer"). His travel
companions were both chosen for their health, ability and loyalty to each
other; Fawcett chose only two companions in order to travel lighter and with
less notice to native tribes, as some were hostile towards outsiders.

On 20 April 1925 his final expedition departed from [Cuiabá](/wiki/Cuiab%C3%A1
"Cuiabá"). In addition to his two principal companions, Fawcett was
accompanied by two Brazilian labourers, two horses, eight mules, and a pair of
dogs. The last communication from the expedition was on 29 May 1925 when
Fawcett wrote, in a letter to his wife delivered by a native runner, that he
was ready to go into unexplored territory with only Jack and Raleigh. They
were reported to be crossing the [Upper Xingu](/wiki/Xingu_River "Xingu
River"), a [southeastern](/wiki/Ordinal_directions "Ordinal directions")
[tributary](/wiki/Tributary "Tributary") river of the [River
Amazon](/wiki/Amazon_River "Amazon River"). The final letter, written from
[Dead Horse Camp](/wiki/Dead_Horse_Camp "Dead Horse Camp"), gave their
location and was generally optimistic.

Many people assumed that local [Indians](/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Brazil
"Indigenous peoples in Brazil") killed them, as several tribes were nearby at
the time: the [Kalapalos](/wiki/Kalapalo "Kalapalo"), the last tribe to have
seen them, the Arumás, [Suyás](/wiki/Suy%C3%A1 "Suyá"), and the
[Xavantes](/wiki/Xavante_people "Xavante people") whose territory they were
entering. The Kalapalo have an oral story of the arrival of three explorers
which states that the three went east, and after five days the Kalapalo
noticed that the group no longer made camp fires. The Kalapalo say that a very
violent tribe most likely killed them. However, both of the younger men were
lame and ill when last seen, and there is not any proof that they were
murdered. It is plausible that they died of natural causes in the Brazilian
jungle.

In 1927, a name-plate of Fawcett was found with an Indian tribe. In June 1933,
a [theodolite](/wiki/Theodolite "Theodolite") compass belonging to Fawcett was
found near the Baciary Indians of [Mato Grosso](/wiki/Mato_Grosso "Mato
Grosso") by Colonel Aniceto Botelho. However, the name-plate was from
Fawcett's expedition five years earlier and had most likely been given as a
gift to the chief of that Indian tribe. The compass was proved to have been
left behind before he entered the jungle on his final journey.[21][22][23]

#### Dead Horse
Camp[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Percy_Fawcett&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Dead Horse Camp")]

**Dead Horse Camp** , or **Fawcett’s camp** , is one of the major camps that
Fawcett made on his final journey. This encampment was his last known
location.[24]

From Dead Horse Camp, Fawcett wrote to his wife about the hardships that he
and his companions had faced, his coordinates, his doubts in Raleigh Rimmel,
and of his plans for the near future. He concludes his message with, “You need
have no fear of any failure...”[24]

One question remaining about Dead Horse Camp concerns a discrepancy in the
coordinates Fawcett gave for the camp. In the letter to his wife, he wrote:
"Here we are at Dead Horse Camp, latitude 11 degrees 43' South and longitude
54 degrees 35' West, the spot where my horse died in 1920" ([11°43′S 54°35′W﻿
/ ﻿11.717°S 54.583°W﻿ / -11.717;
-54.583](//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Percy_Fawcett&params=11_43_S_54_35_W_)).
However, in a report to the [North American Newspaper
Alliance](/wiki/North_American_Newspaper_Alliance "North American Newspaper
Alliance") he gave the coordinates as [13°43′S 54°35′W﻿ / ﻿13.717°S 54.583°W﻿
/ -13.717;
-54.583](//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Percy_Fawcett&params=13_43_S_54_35_W_).[25]

The discrepancy may have been a [typographical](/wiki/Typographical
"Typographical") error. However, he may have intentionally concealed the
location to prevent others from using his notes to find the lost city.[26] It
may have also been an attempt to dissuade any rescue attempts; Fawcett had
stated that if he disappeared, no [rescue party](/wiki/Search_and_rescue
"Search and rescue") should be sent because the danger was too great.[25]

## Posthumous controversy and
speculations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Percy_Fawcett&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Posthumous controversy and speculations")]

### Rumours and unverified
reports[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Percy_Fawcett&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Rumours and unverified reports")]

During the ensuing decades, various groups mounted several rescue expeditions,
without success. They heard only various rumours that could not be verified.
In addition to reports that Fawcett had been killed by Indians or wild
animals, there was a tale that Fawcett had [lost his memory](/wiki/Amnesia
"Amnesia") and lived out his life as the chief of a tribe of
[cannibals](/wiki/Cannibalism "Cannibalism").

While a fictitious tale estimated that 100 would-be-rescuers died on several
expeditions attempting to discover Fawcett's fate[27], the actual toll was
only one - a sole man who ventured after him alone.[28] One of the earliest
expeditions was commanded by American explorer [George Miller
Dyott](/wiki/George_Miller_Dyott "George Miller Dyott"). In 1927 he claimed to
have found evidence of Fawcett's death at the hands of the
[Aloique](/w/index.php?title=Aloique&action=edit&redlink=1 "Aloique \(page
does not exist\)") Indians, but his story was unconvincing. From 1930–31,
[Aloha Wanderwell](/wiki/Aloha_Wanderwell#Brazil "Aloha Wanderwell") used her
seaplane to try to land on the Amazon River in the Matto Grosso to find him.
After an emergency landing and living with the Bororo Tribe for 6 weeks, Aloha
and Walter Flew back to Brazil, with no luck. A 1951 expedition unearthed
human bones that were found later to be unrelated to Fawcett or his
companions.

### Villas-Bôas
story[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Percy_Fawcett&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Villas-Bôas story")]

Danish explorer [Arne Falk-Rønne](/wiki/Arne_Falk-R%C3%B8nne "Arne Falk-
Rønne") journeyed to the [Mato Grosso](/wiki/Mato_Grosso "Mato Grosso") during
the 1960s. In a 1991 book, he wrote that he learned of Fawcett's fate from
[Orlando Villas-Bôas](/wiki/Villas-B%C3%B4as_brothers "Villas-Bôas
brothers")[29], who had heard it from one of Fawcett's murderers. Allegedly,
Fawcett and his companions had a mishap on the river and lost most of the
gifts they'd brought along for the Indian tribes. Continuing without gifts was
a serious breach of protocol; since the expedition members were all more or
less seriously ill at the time, the Kalapalo tribe they encountered decided to
kill them. The bodies of Jack Fawcett and Raleigh Rimell were thrown into the
river; Colonel Fawcett, considered an old man and therefore distinguished,
received a proper burial. Falk-Rønne visited the Kalapalo tribe and reported
that one of the tribesmen confirmed Villas-Bôas's story about how and why
Fawcett had been killed.

### Fawcett's
Bones[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Percy_Fawcett&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: Fawcett's Bones")]

In 1951, [Orlando Villas-Bôas](/wiki/Villas-B%C3%B4as_brothers "Villas-Bôas
brothers"), activist for indigenous peoples, supposedly received the actual
remaining skeletal bones of Fawcett and had them analysed scientifically. The
analysis allegedly confirmed the bones to be Fawcett's, but his son Brian
Fawcett (1906–1984) refused to accept this. Villas-Bôas claimed that Brian was
too interested in making money from books about his father's disappearance.
Later scientific analysis confirmed that the bones were not Fawcett's.[30] As
of 1965, the bones reportedly rested in a box in the flat of one of the
Villas-Bôas brothers in [São Paulo](/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo "São Paulo").[31]

In 1998, English explorer [Benedict Allen](/wiki/Benedict_Allen "Benedict
Allen") went to talk to the Kalapalo Indians, said by Villas-Bôas to have
confessed to having killed the three Fawcett expedition members. An elder of
the Kalapalo, Vajuvi, claimed during a filmed BBC interview with Allen that
the bones found by Villas-Bôas some 45 years before were not really
Fawcett's.[32][33] Vajuvi also denied that his tribe had any part in the
Fawcetts' disappearance. No conclusive evidence supports either statement.

### Russian
documentary[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Percy_Fawcett&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Russian documentary")]

In 2003, a Russian documentary film, "Проклятье золота инков / Экспедиция
Перси Фоссета в Амазонку" (_The Curse of the Incas ' Gold / Expedition of
Percy Fawcett to the Amazon_), was released as a part of the television series
"Тайны века" (_Mysteries of the Century_). Among other things, the film
emphasizes the recent expedition of Oleg Aliyev to the presumed approximate
place of Fawcett's last whereabouts and Aliyev's findings, impressions and
presumptions about Fawcett's fate.[34]

### Commune in the
jungle[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Percy_Fawcett&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: Commune in the jungle")]

On 21 March 2004, the British newspaper _[The Observer](/wiki/The_Observer
"The Observer")_ reported that television director Misha Williams, who had
studied Fawcett's private papers, believed that Fawcett had not intended to
return to Britain but rather meant to found a
[commune](/wiki/Commune_\(intentional_community\) "Commune \(intentional
community\)") in the jungle based on [theosophical](/wiki/Theosophy
"Theosophy") principles and the worship of his son Jack.[35] Williams
explained his research in some detail in the preface to his play _AmaZonia_ ,
first performed in April 2004.[36]

### Grann's _Lost City of
Z_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Percy_Fawcett&action=edit&section=12 "Edit
section: Grann's Lost City of Z")]

Main article: [_The Lost City of Z_ (book)](/wiki/The_Lost_City_of_Z_\(book\)
"The Lost City of Z \(book\)")

In 2005, _[The New Yorker](/wiki/The_New_Yorker "The New Yorker")_ staff
writer [David Grann](/wiki/David_Grann "David Grann") visited the Kalapalo
tribe and reported that it had apparently preserved an oral history about
Fawcett, among the first Europeans the tribe had ever seen. The oral account
said that Fawcett and his party had stayed at their village and then left,
heading eastward. The Kalapalos warned Fawcett and his companions that if they
went that way they would be killed by the "fierce Indians" who occupied that
territory, but Fawcett insisted on going. The Kalapalos observed smoke from
the expedition’s campfire each evening for five days before it disappeared.
The Kalapalos said they were sure the fierce Indians had killed them.[14] The
article also reports that a monumental civilisation known as
[Kuhikugu](/wiki/Kuhikugu "Kuhikugu") may have actually existed near where
Fawcett was searching, as discovered recently by archaeologist [Michael
Heckenberger](/wiki/Michael_Heckenberger "Michael Heckenberger") and
others.[37] Grann's findings are further detailed in his book _[The Lost City
of Z](/wiki/The_Lost_City_of_Z_\(book\) "The Lost City of Z \(book\)")_
(2009).

## In popular
culture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Percy_Fawcett&action=edit&section=14 "Edit
section: In popular culture")]

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png) | This article **appears to contain[trivial, minor, or unrelated](/wiki/Wikipedia:What_Wikipedia_is_not#Wikipedia_is_not_an_indiscriminate_collection_of_information "Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not") references to [popular culture](/wiki/Wikipedia:%22In_popular_culture%22_content "Wikipedia:"In popular culture" content")**. ---|---  
  
  * Was the subject of an episode of _[Digging for the Truth](/wiki/Digging_for_the_Truth "Digging for the Truth")_.
  * [Arthur Conan Doyle](/wiki/Arthur_Conan_Doyle "Arthur Conan Doyle") based his [Professor Challenger](/wiki/Professor_Challenger "Professor Challenger") character partly on Fawcett, and stories of the "Lost City of Z" became the basis for his novel _[The Lost World](/wiki/The_Lost_World_\(Conan_Doyle_novel\) "The Lost World \(Conan Doyle novel\)")._[38]
  * A contemporary reviewer of [Evelyn Waugh](/wiki/Evelyn_Waugh "Evelyn Waugh")'s novel _[A Handful of Dust](/wiki/A_Handful_of_Dust "A Handful of Dust")_ suggested he may have derived the plot partly from Fawcett's disappearance.[39] The novel's hero vanishes into the Brazilian jungle and is kept prisoner there.
  * Fawcett has been proposed as a possible inspiration for [Indiana Jones](/wiki/Indiana_Jones "Indiana Jones"), the fictional archaeologist/adventurer.[40][41] A fictionalised version of Fawcett aids Jones in the novel _[Indiana Jones and the Seven Veils](/wiki/Indiana_Jones_and_the_Seven_Veils "Indiana Jones and the Seven Veils")_.[42])
  * Fawcett was a prototype of Percy Foster, fictional explorer in the Russian-language novel _[The grave of Tame-Tung](https://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%9C%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%B8%D0%BB%D0%B0_%D0%A2%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%B5-%D0%A2%D1%83%D0%BD%D0%B3%D0%B0 "ru:Могила Таме-Тунга")_. There, Foster and his son became obsessed with riches of Indians and were killed by their former friend Raleigh Rimer (based on Raleigh Rimmel) to prevent pillaging.
  * According to an article in _Comics Scene_ No. 45, Fawcett was the inspiration of Kent Allard, an alter ego of [the Shadow](/wiki/The_Shadow_\(fictional_character\) "The Shadow \(fictional character\)").[32]
  * Director [Pete Docter](/wiki/Pete_Docter "Pete Docter") named Fawcett as one of the inspirations for the character Charles F. Muntz, the antagonist of the [Pixar](/wiki/Pixar "Pixar") film _[Up](/wiki/Up_\(2009_film\) "Up \(2009 film\)")_.
  * [David Grann](/wiki/David_Grann "David Grann")'s _[The Lost City of Z](/wiki/The_Lost_City_of_Z_\(book\) "The Lost City of Z \(book\)")_ was optioned by [Brad Pitt](/wiki/Brad_Pitt "Brad Pitt")'s [Plan B](/wiki/Plan_B_Entertainment "Plan B Entertainment") production company and [Paramount Pictures](/wiki/Paramount_Pictures "Paramount Pictures"). [James Gray](/wiki/James_Gray_\(film_director\) "James Gray \(film director\)") directed [the film](/wiki/The_Lost_City_of_Z_\(film\) "The Lost City of Z \(film\)"), which stars [Charlie Hunnam](/wiki/Charlie_Hunnam "Charlie Hunnam") as Fawcett and was released in April 2017.
  * _The Cruise of the Condor_ (1933), one of [W. E. Johns](/wiki/W._E._Johns "W. E. Johns")' "[Biggles](/wiki/Biggles "Biggles")" stories, is inspired by Fawcett's search for "Z".
  * Writers [Douglas Preston](/wiki/Douglas_Preston "Douglas Preston") and [Lincoln Child](/wiki/Lincoln_Child "Lincoln Child") mentioned in their books that Percy Fawcett was a great-great uncle of [Aloysius Pendergast](/wiki/Aloysius_Pendergast "Aloysius Pendergast") on his mother’s side.
  * The plot of the first episode of the television programme _[Hooten& the Lady](/wiki/Hooten_%26_the_Lady "Hooten & the Lady")_ was about the search for Fawcett's camp.
  * In [Hergé](/wiki/Herg%C3%A9 "Hergé")'s adventure of [Tintin](/wiki/Tintin_\(character\) "Tintin \(character\)") _[L'Oreille Cassée](/wiki/The_Broken_Ear "The Broken Ear")_, Fawcett is believed to be the model for Ridgewell, an explorer disappeared for ten years who has become known as "the white old man" a member of the Arumbaya tribe.
  * Peter Fleming's book Brazilian Adventure is the story of his part in an expedition to find Fawcett. Fleming's book was first published in 1933. Peter was the brother of Ian who wrote the James Bond books.
  * The 2017 [Osprey Games](/wiki/Osprey_Publishing "Osprey Publishing") [Eurogame](/wiki/Eurogame "Eurogame") _The Lost Expedition_ , designed by Peer Sylvester, with artwork by [Garen Ewing](/wiki/Garen_Ewing "Garen Ewing"), is based on Percy Fawcett's expeditions.[43]
